Claim.origin: [Old French, from clamer to call, claim, from Latin clamare to shout, proclaim]

1 a.definition: a demand for something (as money) due or believed to be duea demand for a benefit (as under the workers' compensation law) or contractual payment (as under an insurance policy)

sub_terms.b: a paper embodying such a demand [filing a with the court]

2.definition: a title to something (as a debt or privilege) in the possession of another [assigned her to the proceeds]

3 a.definition: a right to seek a judicial remedy arising from a wrong or injury suffered [a plaintiff who has been injured in an accident has…one for a broken arm, another for a ruptured spleen, and so forth "J. H. Friedenthal"]the formal assertion of such a right [bringing a in the district court]

sub_terms.b: [a plaintiff stated a against a seller of applesauce when she alleged that her children…ate the applesauce…and were then so discomforted that they had to have their stomachs pumped "J. J. White and R. S. Summers"] see also
sub_terms.c: a right to payment or to an equitable remedy as set forth in the Bankruptcy Code see also

3 a.note: A cause of action may encompass more than one claim as the term is used in sense 3a.Claimis often used to meancause of action, however, esp. in modern federal practice.

4.definition: a formal assertion made by an applicant for a patent of the novelty and patentability of an invention with a description of the invention and its purpose
